title: Have you ever written a book that you haven't shown to anyone else? - Quora

response.answer_text: I never show any of my books to a single other person until I’m done with my “final” draft—not even my wife, who’s also my editor. Only when I make it as perfect as possibly do I give it to her. Then she goes through, finds all my mistakes, and I spend another month making it as perfect as possible … again. And it’s only then that anyone outside the house sees it. That being the case, I have several “trunk novels” from years ago that no one but me has ever seen, and I hope it stays that way.

I kept a diary during film school called Second Act Funk. As a diary, it sucks. It's dated, filled with descriptions of people and productions that are of no interest to anyone. As a novel, it has real potential. A lawyer has a midlife crisis and goes to film school. Unfortunately, he makes the worst student film in the world and has to use his legal skills to graduate… If you are talking about published works, I have nonfiction, that I hide in the closet.

response.answer_text: Ahhhh! What a great question. It reminds me of an Oscar Wild anecdote: Oscar had written a book, but it sold horribly. Some 5,000 copies were sent to him by the disgusted book seller. … Some time later, Oscar was overheard mentioning that he had a 6,000 volume library, 5,000 of which he had actually written himself.  In my case, well, check out this listing on AMAZON: Defining and compiling terminfo definitions for the UNICOS operating systems: David Ecale If you are interested in buying a copy, I have the only three extant copies in existence. Then again, just FORGEDDABOUDIT! And, use Xterm in Linux.
Well, no. But I have written books that I had a hard time getting anyone else to read! (I am not destined for best-sellerdom, it seems. Sigh.)
Ha! Yes! I have a small library of exploratory or first draft books that I never developed. This could be me bragging about my creativity or me kicking myself for laziness.
